newsitem.title: USA: OPTIONS - Heavy selling in dlr/yen short dates.
newsitem.headline: OPTIONS - Heavy selling in dlr/yen short dates.

text.p: Implied volatilities for dollar/yen options declined substantially in U.S. trading Thursday amid active selling of short-dated options, traders said.
"We're seeing fairly aggressive selling of the yen vols in the front end, but the risk reversal hasn't moved," said Soma Rao, options sales manager for Smith Barney.

The one-month 25-delta risk reversal remained sharply skewed for yen calls at 2.2/2.4 as the supply/demand imbalance that developed in the wake of dollar/yen's plunge toward 110 last week kept yen calls strongly bid, dealers said.
"There is still a lot of interest to buy yen calls for protection on the downside. Both corporations and funds are driving the demand," Rao said.
Risk reversals are a gauge of market preference for calls or puts.

The dollar climbed back above 114 yen this morning after the overall U.S. April trade deficit was reported at a smaller than expected $8.36 billion. The deficit with Japan grew by 5.1 percent to $4.84 billion.
Foreign currency market participants said Japanese data released earlier this week showing the nation's trade gap with the U.S. continued to widen in May was worrisome.
"The market is still afraid of a sharp move down" in dollar/yen, said Rao.
One-month dollar/yen volatility had dived to 11.6/11.9 percent by midday, a decline of 1.5 percentage points from late Wednesday. One-year was off about 0.4 point at 10.6/10.9 percent.
Traders said selling interest was concentrated especially in one-month at-the-money options, but that interest also extended to two- and three-months and further out the curve.
A $500 million trade overnight involving 115-strike yen puts with one-week maturity at 14.75 percent to 14.25 percent volatility likely weighed on the short end of the curve, said a U.S. bank trader.
In addition, interest in out-of-the-money dollar puts down to the 102 strike and selling of out-of-the-money yen puts and dollar calls was seen overnight, traders said.
There was also talk that a large exotic options position with a trigger of 112.50 yen was being protected.

Shorter-dated dollar/mark volatilities continued to weaken, with one-month slipping 0.2 point to 8.8/9.1 percent, gradually steepening the curve's upward slope. Meanwhile, one-year was slightly firmer at 9.4/9.6 percent.
The U.S. bank trader said the sale of a $500 million, three-month low-delta dollar/guilder position may have had a spillover weakening effect on shorter-dated dollar/mark volatility.
